In the first four months I worked for Allied I was passed off to four different lines managers. The last of the four managers I wasn't even notified was my new manager until they called me and introduced them self as my new manager. Of the four, not one of them could consistently answer phone calls or emails citing everything from meetings and holidays, meaning there's no handoff, to phone and computer problems, which is odd for an IT outsourcing company riddled with so many IT problems. 

After five weeks of asking what day we're paid on and getting no response, I had to threaten to walk off the job before I was offered an "apology bonus" to keep me on site for another week until I was paid. As far as benefits go, Allied offered none as with most outsourcing firms but the final straw was when I noticed extra deductions from my paycheck and was then informed that the company no longer pays for sick days meaning two and a half days pay were deducted from my salary after the fact, with no prior notice and in direct breach of my contract as a permanent employee. 

These are just the major points of why you should avoid working for Allied Worldwide as a whole, but aside from which there were multiple pay disputes, taxation issues and a disjointed managerial structure in general. The hassle of working for this lacklustre company isn't nearly worth the less than average pay and total lack of benefits they offer.

The company is growing as can be seen with two acquisitions within the last year which is not only exciting it shows to me they want to be market leaders in their field and the firm of choice in Consultancy Engineering.

Yes, the job is challenging (whose job isn’t?) but with the help and assistance of the team I work with as well as a massive onus been put on team ethic, we all help each other. 

In conclusion, my time here in ByrneLooby has been great, I thoroughly enjoy my job, the people I work with and report to so I couldn’t ask for anything better. If you want to pursue a career be it in Finance or Consultancy Engineering I would highly recommend working here.

column25:
Where do I start? I only wish that I could have found a review from a previous employee on glassdoor. 

I had my suspicions of what type of working environment I might find myself working in from the interview stage. I was interviewed 3 separate times by 3 different people in one day all asking the same questions which lasted for a ridiculous 1 hour and 20 minutes. For my second interview I was asked to buy and read the book titled "how to win friends and influence people" which I did but was not asked anything at all about the book at my second interview. Complete waste of my time and money. Second interview was essentially the same as first interview but with a role play. I was also asked to buy a second book before starting work, which I did and was also never asked to produce this again. More money wasted.

When researching the company before interview, all I could find was a couple of bad reviews on Google from a past client and candidate. I tried to put these negative comments out of my head but after starting work here, it didn't take long to find out that those couple of comments actually painted quite a good picture of what this place is about. 

I also found out that the company has been around for roughly 10 years and had only 3 employees. 1 is the owner, another is the owners sister and another has been there around 4 years. I couldn't help thinking why a company that has been around for so long had so few employees, but I soon found out. 

There is no training to speak of whatsoever (certainly not what I would consider training) There is no reviewing progress as you go along or constructive feedback given. I imagine the reason for this is that they have had so many people come and go that if they have ever given decent training, they had definitely given up. I was also told that they had went through at least a dozen trainees in a 6 month period before I started. Quite a high number considering the size of the business. Since leaving I have learned that their attempt to open a second office in Belfast has failed. This is no surprise as i've seen how they manage new employees. 

Atmosphere is extremely uncomfortable, boring and no sense of team spirit. There is always a very obvious tension in the room which does not make for a pleasant working environment. I have personally never worked in a more uncomfortable environment and hope I never will again. 

They are extremely unwelcoming to new employees and as much as I tried to build a relationship with my new co-workers, I could tell that my efforts were neither appreciated or welcomed. 

There is an unspoken rule that no-one goes home until the boss goes home even though the "official" finishing time is 6. If the boss is still there at 6.30 then you must be also. Everyone literally waits until he leaves before finishing up. Also extremely uncomfortable.

The way the everyone talks about their clients and candidates is extremely unprofessional and derogatory in some cases. I found this particularly hard to listen to on a daily basis.

Working at Greywoods is without a doubt an experience I will never forget, but for all the wrong reasons.

Guidewire is a great, people centric organisation.  There is a strong focus on values self-organisation and self-management. People are trusted, and expected to do the right thing.  Salary and benefits are very good and linked to your performance in a very fair and reasonable way.  Growth in the Dublin office has been really strong over the last few years, and will continue for the foreseeable future. 

Product Development teams are setup for success as self-organising 'pods' that define and run their own Agile practices and processes.  These pods are generally about 5 to 8 people with a product manager, 3 to 5 engineers and 1 to 2 QAs.  Pods are collected into tribes with specific purposes.

Product Development in Dublin covers 3 main areas: 
(1) Digital, which encompasses  the online 'Digital' aspects of the product set delivering a set of online digital experiences targeted at different roles.  
(2) Suite - which covers the engineering and delivery of elements the underlying product suite.
(3) Content - delivers market specific enhancements of the product for specific regional markets.
column25:
I would say that in Guidewire Product Development there aren't many cons.  It's a really great place to work.  

If pushed the only cons I would list are around the maturity of the products.

We have been developing these products for nearly  2 decades, there is a lot of existing software.  This has been developed and enhanced over many years.  Some areas of the product suite are more modern than others, some have been modernised, some  haven't.  This can present a challenge for people looking to develop 'green fields' applications.  As we  grow and develop we tackle these challenges but it's not the same as starting with a blank sheet.

The only other con worth a mention is the use of a internal language Gosu.  It's a java like language that provided access to key language features before they were available in Java.  It's straight forward but if you are very sensitive to with language you use, this might be a turn off.  Most strong engineers are not bothered by this - it's just another C-like language.

column25:

- Projects often go on hold and restart with little or no warning, meaning that engineers are at times under a lot of pressure. It can be difficult at times to get assistance with this, but management are usually quick to address unreasonable deadlines and help make sure that each engineer has the resources that they need.

- The strict quality control policies often slow down the issuing of projects, as everything has to be checked and approved by two separate members of staff. As all staff are often busy and under pressure themselves, there can be a bit of a backlog when it comes to checking. 

- Since the office is in the city centre, commuting can be very difficult at peak times. 

- When project deadlines are looming, it is sometimes necessary to put in overtime into the evenings or early in the morning.

Mathworks is a jewel within all these fast-growing, hyped-up companies. If you are looking for a job where you are dealing with professional and intelligent people, which take their work seriously and are passionate about the products, you have come to the right place . The team is a mixture of all ages and nationalities and the  atmosphere is one of mutual respect and helpfulness. People sell well, because they believe in the product, and there is a complete lack of the  ultra-competitive ,aggressive sales mentality  and rivalry that poison so many sales environments. Territories are clear and well organised, and there is advise and coaching but no micro-management. 

You never stop learning at MathWorks, and if you like Science and Computing, you are in heaven. The Managers are fair and they are "proper" managers, that care about their team and have the experience. MathWorks is a no-nonsense , friendly company with dedicated , hard-working employees. The salary and benefits are good and get better, the longer you are with MathWorks. Unlike a lot of the very "young, fast and short-lived"  sales jobs,  MathWorks provides a  stable, mature and steadily growing  team and a nice ,modern office right in the Centre of Galway. It is so far the best company I have worked for.

This is my 4th start up and by far thee best company I've ever had the pleasure of working for.

Some companies have wishy washy missions statements about culture, diversity and values and do hardly anything to evidence this.

Not here at New Relic! They wear their hearts of their sleeve and adhere to the principles they want to follow: Honesty & Authenticity, Integrity, Diversity and Gender and GBLT Equality. A true Meritocracy! The tone of any company is set right at the very top by its leadership team and flows down right down to the bottom. Relic have got this right and have somehow managed to maintain that true start up spirit of one team and great culture and nurtured it and brought out the best of it and grown with! Its so easy to lose this and just become yet another corporate.

A few living examples of this of what I hear people around me consistently say: " I have everything I want here" "My manager is great and gives me flexibility and space" "this is the greatest company I have ever worked for, I LOVE IT". The greatest asset of any company is it's people. Relic value and recognise this. Also ... I hear "Do the right thing by your customers, make them successful and you will in turn be successful". My last employer was completely the opposite to this and a huge mistake! Unfortunately it's human nature to not call out good things or really appreciate them when you have them, only when you no longer have them!. 

I have not even mentioned the Product yet. I will the marketing department do that as they they are more eloquent than me: but the platform, It's roots and the way Relic continues to delight it's customers is AMAZING!

The CEO is special and one of it's greatest assets; some one who inspires people and has charisma and is a real genius! My last CEO was completely the opposite to this was robotic by comparison.  He also has a litmus test for hiring people "would I share a car journey with this person": in other words you need to be a cultural fit to work at New Relic. "love your Mondays"  I hear him saying, in other words love what you do, and if you don't, go find something that will. Sorry Lew, giving away the secret sauce!!

The new shiny, amazing, inspirational, wonderful EMEA HQ Dublin office is nearly worthy of all the wonderful people that work in it!

column25:
Where to begin......

I must say that all comments are completely my own opinion. 

Whilst I was there, we had a Questions/Answer session with one of the Directors. We submitted our questions anonymously beforehand. One question was why they ask us to do so much overtime and UNPAID. What really frustrated me was their complete avoidance of answering this question and they gave an answer any politician would be proud of. The Czech Labor Law states that it is illigal to work more than 5 consecutive days in the Czech Republic, yet they are "encouraging" us to work across weekends. If you didn't work on weekends like myself (I had no desire/push to do so) you were looked down upon as a "part-timer". 

It sucks the energy from you. After making hundreds of calls a week and working an additional couple of hours every night, you naturally want to relax on a weekend....not work more. Work-Life balance is key. I think, literally a handful of employees were married. It is not a Job for someone with a family. You have no balance at all. 

It is hectic environment but feels like a school. You have to have lunch between certain times and you feel bad even making a coffee out of the regulated breaks. 

The staff turnover is absolutely astonishing. From the group who started alongside myself, only 2 remain as far as I am aware. 

Unprofessional. In my opinion, NonStop is the most Unprofessional Professional company I have come across. You have to dress formally (suits) when there is no need to. Furthermore, the attitude and lifestyles of some of the employees are utterly disgraceful and I can say that they would certainly struggle in most other companies. 

Wages. They try to incentivize you to make sales by paying you a very low sum of money per month. It does not work in my opinion at all. The first few months in Prague, your salary is so low you honestly find it difficult to get by.

They're very good at supporting staff when it comes to self-development, further education and training and career planning.
People are expected to work hard but there's a brilliant ethos in terms of work-life balance. People do their stuff and go home to their families, there's no stupidity about trying to work people to death. There's also great holidays and - shock horror! - people are urged to take them!
Despite the rapid growth over the past couple of years, there's a lovely atmosphere to the place, a great sense of fun and people treated each other with respect.
In other places I worked there was a lot of BS from the top about listening to the workers and I thought it would be the same here, but it's definitely not. This is not a con per se, but over the years I felt this was a topic of discontent for many people. Because it is still a very flat (and developing) org, it takes quite a lot of commitment and work to move (upwards and sideways).  If you are looking for an easy way up or a quick career change you will be disappointed. For me, this was never an issue as my motivators/rewards are not associated with movement but with development opportunities instead. Younger generations need to understand not everything happens at the speed of light...
There is still a lot to be done, to develop a unique corporate cultural entity - "Company culture" is thrown left right and centre but I did not feel it meant the same throughout the org. (also not necessarily a con). While there are a set of company values, every department ended up living by a different set of values and work culture. 
Additionally, the company doesn't take advantage of each office's uniqueness. I.e.: social/experience events and initiatives are pushed top down, and there seems to be little room to do things locally without it being overly scrutinized or shut down because it can't be pushed org . wide (or so was my perception). Things that made sense and were meaningful celebrations (or ways to celebrate) in the main office were pushed to other locations with (what seemed) little regard for relevance, and sometimes initiatives fell flat because of that.

This is my 4th start up and by far thee best company I've ever had the pleasure of working for.

Some companies have wishy washy missions statements about culture, diversity and values and do hardly anything to evidence this.

Not here at New Relic! They wear their hearts of their sleeve and adhere to the principles they want to follow: Honesty & Authenticity, Integrity, Diversity and Gender and GBLT Equality. A true Meritocracy! The tone of any company is set right at the very top by its leadership team and flows down right down to the bottom. Relic have got this right and have somehow managed to maintain that true start up spirit of one team and great culture and nurtured it and brought out the best of it and grown with! Its so easy to lose this and just become yet another corporate.

A few living examples of this of what I hear people around me consistently say: " I have everything I want here" "My manager is great and gives me flexibility and space" "this is the greatest company I have ever worked for, I LOVE IT". The greatest asset of any company is it's people. Relic value and recognise this. Also ... I hear "Do the right thing by your customers, make them successful and you will in turn be successful". My last employer was completely the opposite to this and a huge mistake! Unfortunately it's human nature to not call out good things or really appreciate them when you have them, only when you no longer have them!. 

I have not even mentioned the Product yet. I will the marketing department do that as they they are more eloquent than me: but the platform, It's roots and the way Relic continues to delight it's customers is AMAZING!

The CEO is special and one of it's greatest assets; some one who inspires people and has charisma and is a real genius! My last CEO was completely the opposite to this was robotic by comparison.  He also has a litmus test for hiring people "would I share a car journey with this person": in other words you need to be a cultural fit to work at New Relic. "love your Mondays"  I hear him saying, in other words love what you do, and if you don't, go find something that will. Sorry Lew, giving away the secret sauce!!

The new shiny, amazing, inspirational, wonderful EMEA HQ Dublin office is nearly worthy of all the wonderful people that work in it!
column25:
